Package com.intellij.util.ui

Class JBScalableIcon

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.intellij.ui.scale.UserScaleContextSupport
      • com.intellij.util.ui.JBScalableIcon
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ScalableIcon, ScaleContextAware, javax.swing.Icon
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    JBUI.JBIcon

    public abstract class JBScalableIcon
extends UserScaleContextSupport
implements ScalableIcon
    A scalable icon, UserScaleContext aware, assuming vector-based painting (system scale independent).

      • isIconPreScaled

      • setIconPreScaled

        protected void setIconPreScaled(boolean preScaled)

      • withIconPreScaled

        public JBScalableIcon withIconPreScaled(boolean preScaled)
        The pre-scaled state of the icon indicates whether the initial size of the icon is pre-scaled (by the global user scale) or not. If the size is not pre-scaled, then there're two approaches to deal with it: 1) scale its initial size right away and store; 2) scale its initial size every time it's requested. The 2nd approach is preferable because of the the following. Scaling of the icon may involve not only USR_SCALE but OBJ_SCALE as well. In which case applying all the scale factors and then rounding (the size is integer, the scale factors are not) gives more accurate result than rounding and then scaling.

        For example, say we have an icon of 15x15 initial size, USR_SCALE is 1.5f, OBJ_SCALE is 1,5f. Math.round(Math.round(15 * USR_SCALE) * OBJ_SCALE) = 35 Math.round(15 * USR_SCALE * OBJ_SCALE) = 34

        Thus, JBUI.scale(MyIcon.create(w, h)) is preferable to MyIcon.create(JBUI.scale(w), JBUI.scale(h)). Here [w, h] is "raw" unscaled size.

        Parameters:
        preScaled - whether the icon is pre-scaled
        Returns:
        the icon in the provided pre-scaled state
        See Also:
        (JBScalableIcon)

      • setAutoUpdateScaleContext

        protected void setAutoUpdateScaleContext(boolean autoUpdate)
        Sets whether the scale context should be auto-updated by the Scaler. This ensures that scaleVal(double) always uses up-to-date scale. This is useful when the icon doesn't need to recalculate its internal sizes on the scale context update and so it doesn't need the result of the update and/or it doesn't listen for updates. Otherwise, the value should be set to false and the scale context should be updated manually.

        By default the value is true.

      • getScale

        public float getScale()

        getScale in interface ScalableIcon
        Returns:
        the scale of the icon relative to its origin

      • scale

        public javax.swing.Icon scale(float scale)
        Description copied from interface: ScalableIcon
        Creates and returns a scaled instance of the icon. The icon is scaled relative to its origin, that is scale(1f) will return the icon in its original scale. To scale this instance by n times: scale(n * getScale()). Note that the methods Icon.getIconWidth() and Icon.getIconHeight() should return the scaled size of the icon.
        Specified by:
        scale in interface ScalableIcon
        Parameters:
        scale - scale
        Returns:
        scaled icon instance

      • updateScaleContext

        public boolean updateScaleContext(UserScaleContext ctx)
        Description copied from interface: ScaleContextAware
        Updates the current context with the state of the provided context. If ctx is null, then updates the current context via ScaleContext.update() and returns the result.
        Specified by:
        updateScaleContext in interface ScaleContextAware
        Parameters:
        ctx - the new scale context
        Returns:
